properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T23:36:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T13:59:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0292233102.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix of snow, ice pellets, freezing rain and rain tonight. A frontal system moving across northern BC tonight will bring a mix of heavy snow, ice pellets and freezing rain before transitioning to rain on Monday. In Stewart, heavy snow tonight will produce 10 to 15 cm before transitioning to rain Monday morning. There exists a risk of freezing rain anywhere in the region during the transition phase late this evening and after midnight. In Kitimat, snow will transition to ice pellets as the front approaches then to rain near midnight as warmer air invades the region. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T15:04:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-25T23:05:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2973629842.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Kitimat, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. A frontal system has brought a wintry mix of snow and freezing rain to many inland communities on the North Coast last night. Freezing precipitation currently observed near Terrace will end this morning as temperatures rise above zero. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T19:14:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T11:34:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0831137568.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls continue in the lee of Lake Winnipeg this morning as cold west winds blow across the lake. Snow squall activity is expected to gradually weaken by the afternoon however further localized accumulations of up to 10 cm are possible by the time the snow tapers off. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T19:59:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T13:12:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3646175554.2020
Area: Poplar River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First accumulating snowfall of the season expected for many areas. Total snowfall: near 5 cm, with higher amounts over elevated terrain. Locations: central, western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: late tonight through Tuesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin over western Newfoundland near midnight tonight, and will spread into central and northern parts of the island by early Tuesday morning. The snow will change to rain over most areas by midday on Tuesday, but may persist through Tuesday afternoon and evening over parts of the Northern and Baie Verte Peninsulas, especially over higher terrain. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-10-27T05:16:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T13:17:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3901214552.2020
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A frontal system will move across central and northern parts of the interior tonight through Monday morning. Snow associated with this system will start early this evening and is expected to change to ice pellets mixed with freezing rain overnight. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm can be expected by Monday morning. As the front moves eastwards, the freezing rain or ice pellets will ease on Monday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-26T15:25:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-25T23:26:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1819965462.2020
Area: Chilcotin, Cariboo - north including Quesnel, Bulkley Valley, Lakes District, Stuart - Nechako
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A frontal system is approaching from the southwest will cross the Yukon today. As it approaches, strong easterly winds of 70 to 100 km/h near the Richardson Mountains will develop. These winds combined with falling snow will give blizzard conditions to the area beginning this morning. Conditions will improve this evening as the system exits the territory. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T03:20:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T11:21:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2438172479.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. A frontal system moving into the southwest Yukon will spread additional snow from the southwestern Yukon to the central Yukon today. Snow will ease later this morning in the southwest as the system crosses the area but persist until this evening elsewhere. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T03:19:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T11:20:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2992073140.2020
Area: Dawson, Mayo, Beaver Creek, Pelly - Carmacks, Whitehorse, Faro - Ross River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall amounts from 15 to 25 cm are expected through today. A frontal system, moving across the northern Gulf of Alaska is spreading significant snowfall amounts from central BC to the southern Yukon. The snow is expected to ease for most areas this afternoon as the front moves eastward. Another frontal system is expected to bring more snow to the Yellowhead region tonight through Tuesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T03:23:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T11:24:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3556534620.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First significant early season snowfall tonight. Locations: northern New Brunswick. Time span: this afternoon and into early Tuesday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin over northern New Brunswick this afternoon and then changeover to rain tonight over most regions before ending Tuesday morning. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected however, more accumulation is likely over higher terrain where temperatures will be colder. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T05:50:44-00:00
